text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay? But people in the old days, maybe your father, you think about it, you know, um, that was pain that you remember. Okay? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Uh. Yeah. Alright. Doctor: So. Uh. So, I just wrote a quick note to you that sort of says your options for your prostate cancer that is getting worse and that’s why PSA and more disease on bone scan. Okay? That’s how I made that decision. You can go with cabazitaxel chemotherapy, supportive care only. That will just keep you comfortable. Or, a clinical trial, ‘cuz again with cabazitaxel, you’re gonna get supportive care. With clinical trial, you’re gonna get supportive care. You know, we’re always here to make sure you – we keep you comfortable. Uh. The clinical trial, you would need to start the enzalutamide, then have a rising PSA Patient: Yep. Doctor: It could be as short as three weeks from now that everything works. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Okay? But again, the logistics of getting the drug, the logistics of you taking it, logistics of getting a PSA, then you coming back down here and get an ARV seven and then having a week for it to come back, it’s . Okay? Patient: Yeah.

text: Patient: And so this is gonna show us if if it worked? Doctor: Yeah so the CAT scan I think one of our concerns was that you also had the lymph node disease. Patient: Right. Yeah. text: Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But I haven’t, I don’t cure anybody with prostate cancer, so I’m getting frustrated in my career. You know? Is there something I can do that has a chance to cure the disease? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The only thing I could think of, so we’re testing the bone marrow transplant idea is being prostate. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So their immune system has not been exposed to prostate tissue. What if we used a female into a male? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: The other things we’re looking at is keeping the male castrated so all the prostate genes are turned off, and then after the new bone marrow gets all happy, you get a couple of pulse of testosterone, not to treat the cancer but to turn on the genes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: To get the immune system. This new immune system, saying what the hell is that? It’s almost like an infection. So we’re in the early stages. We’ve treated two men. I can’t say much other than you know they did pretty well with the transplant part. Uh we’re following them. It’s really designed, my idea is for younger men, you know, less than seventy, and that is younger for me, uh, where, you know, unfortunately, you know prostate cancer grows slowly in most men. You’re probably going to live long enough that this is you know could be really- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, we’re, we’re uh cautiously optimistic. Patient: Yeah.

text: Family Member: But it is holding him, right? Doctor: Some parts of it but I think we have to think about adding something else to the mix here or stopping it. And I just want to double-check. You’re still taking Xtandi? Okay, and are you alternating like number of pills per day or are you just - Patient: Four a day. Doctor: Okay, so you know you don’t have much room to go from that because that’s the max dose. But when you break through from the bone scan it tells me it’s really not working. The stuff that’s being not - you know it’s not in your liver or anything else. Like it’s just still in the bone and you’ve got pain actually suggests we could try a different treatment called Xofigo. And I mentioned this like a while back. This is that radium stuff that Marie Curie discovered many years ago. I don’t know if you guys remember that from elementary school. But it basically kills, you know, cancer in the bones. Well in her case she died because she was carrying too much of it in her pocket. But in patients, it’s now in legit treatment for men with prostate cancer that has gone to bone. Family Member: Does that look - something you inject, like a pill or capsule or something? Doctor: No, it’s actually, they put an I.V. in you and it comes in a – it’s a liquid. It’s like liquid radiation, and they draw it up and then they just inject it in you. It’s like you know, it’s like in, in over a minute, and it’s once a month for six months. The person that is the expert is the radiation oncology doctor, and that person knows how to regulate obviously radiation. This is a form of radiation. Family Member: Is that what they did to him before when he went down there? They - Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Where the pain, where the pain was? Doctor: Uh hum, well there, they radiated you from the outside. You laid down and they beamed it to you, right. This is internal. So when they push it in your bloodstream it goes all around and it lands in the area of the bone that has the cancer. Family Member: Is there side effects? Doctor: Oh yeah, there’s always side effects. Because it’s radiation, some of the side effects could be you know reduced or lower amounts of blood cells in your system, so people could get low white cells, red cells, platelets. Those are your three guys that I always watch out for and in some people, it’s a pretty big dip and you don’t come back. Very rare, but it’s a possibility. Family Member: What do you mean a dip?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
